A Blackbox in the car ?

American road planners are looking for a source of money to repair the declining highway system , and believe they have found the solution in a small black box that can be found on the dashboard of each car .

The devices that record every kilometre driven and report the information to the authorities are at the heart of a controversial attempt by Washington and the state planning offices to revise the outdated system for financing US roads .
The normally rather boring area of road planning has suddenly created an intense debate with colourful alliances .

Libertarians have allied themselves with environmental groups , arguing that the government can use the small boxes to record the driven kilometres – and possibly where they were driven – and then use the information to calculate tax models .
The Tea Party is appalled .
The American Civil Rights Association ( ACLU ) is also deeply concerned and expresses a number of data protection concerns .
But , while Congress cannot agree on action , several states are no longer waiting .
They are currently examining how they can change over the next ten years to a system where drivers pay per mile .
Thousands of drivers have already tested the tachographs , some of which are equipped with GPS monitoring .

“ It is nothing we may only use , ” said Hasan Ikhrata , Managing Director of the Southern California Assn of Governments , who plans to record the miles driven by all Californian drivers in the state from 2025 .

The technology for this is there .
The initiative comes at a time when the Highway Trust Fund , financed from the taxes that US Americans pay at the column of tap , is bankrupt .

Government oil tax of 18.4 cents per gallon ( less than 4 euro cents per litre ) has not increased for 20 years .

“ This is the most sensible alternative in the long term , ” he said .
Bureaucrats call it a mile-based user fee .

Not surprisingly , the idea is appealing to urban liberals , because , for example , the tax could be used to influence driving behaviour in such a way as to reduce congestion and climate-damaging emissions .
